pageContext.description:
A half-length portrait of the chancellor of Anhalt Paulus von Berge (1475-1539), facing left against a dark green background. He is wearing a fur-trimmed cloak and holds a writen sheet in his right hand. 
[Herrschaft, cda 2015]
pageContext.dimensions:
Dimensions of support: 52.1 x 45.3 x 1.1 cm
Dimensions including frame: 62 x 54.6 x 3.8 cm
[Anhaltische Gemälde-Galerie, revised 2011]
pageContext.inscription:
- along the top edge: 
'NASCITVR PAVLVS A BERG ANNO DO. 1475 DEZ 4 / FEBRUAR 1: MORITUR 1539 DIE 26 DECEMBRIS CLI / MACTERICO NONO.'

involvedPersons.remarks:
Lucas Cranach der Ältere (Nachfolger)/Peter Rodelstedt

[Klingen, Cat. Dessau 1996, 34]
involvedPersons.suffix: Follower of Lucas Cranach the Elder

involvedPersons.name: Peter Rodelstedt
involvedPersons.remarks:
Peter Rodelstedt
[Schade, Brief vom 14.07.1960][1]

[1]Klingen, Cat. Dessau 1996, 36]

pageContext.markings:
Reverse of the panel:
The following inscription is on a plaque attached with screws: 
'GRABSCHRIFFT IN DER KIRCHEN / IM IARD: MDXXXIX.AN SANCTSTEPA / NS. TAGE IST VON DIESER WELT ABGSHIDEN, / DER ERBAR PAULVS. V. BERGE: WELCHR IN DAS/ XLV IAR DES HAVSES ANHALTS GETREUER RATH VN/ CANTZLER GEWESEN VND IN SEINEM DIENST ALLE VER/ SATZTE GÜETER DER HERSCHAFFT DVRCH GOTTLICHE/ VORLEIHE WIDER EIN GELOSET DES SEELE DER ALMECHTIGE/ BARMHERTZIG GODT ZV SEIN GERVHE AMEN.'

[Klingen, Cat. Dessau 1996, 34-36]

Reverse on the cradle:

- on the top horizontal batten, left:
paper label 'Gemäldegalerie Dessau / Werkstatt-Tagebuch Nr. [printed stamp] 315a [handwritten with a feather in brown]'
- right:
paper label with cyrillic script ' ??/ Pect. No.[printed] 917 o?[handwritten, pencil]
- on the bottom horizontal batten, left:
paper label with inscription, handwritten in blue ink 'Sächsischer Meister um 1540 / 322 Paulus von Berge, Kanzler in Anhalt-Dessau / Staat 133, ZK 735'
- right:
Cyrillic No., Brush in black '3K 735'

[Anhaltische Gemälde-Galerie, revised 2011]

tests.text:
"Ornamental shapes held in reserve at the bottom of the panel suggest that it was probably part of a larger decorative scheme, more than likely an epitaph."
[Großmann, Untersuchungsbericht 1991][1] 

[1][Klingen, Cat. Dessau 1996, 36]
